name: Rent Arrears (Serious)
short_description: Serious rent arrears at notice and hearing date

arrears_at_notice.weekly_rent: At least 2 months' rent in arrears
arrears_at_notice.monthly_rent: At least 2 months' rent in arrears
arrears_at_notice.quarterly_rent: At least one quarter's rent in arrears (over 3 months)
arrears_at_notice.yearly_rent: At least 3 months' rent in arrears

arrears_at_hearing.requirement: Same level of arrears still outstanding
arrears_at_hearing.note: If arrears reduced below threshold, Ground 8 cannot be used

notice_period.section_8_notice: 2 weeks for Ground 8 only (instead of usual 2 months)
notice_period.accelerated: Shorter notice makes this fastest route

evidence_required: Tenancy agreement with rent amount and due dates
Proof arrears exist at both notice and hearing dates
Proof of service of Section 8 notice

high_probability: Substantial arrears (3+ months) at both notice and hearing
Tenant has made no payments or proposals
Tenant not engaging with possession process
medium_probability: Tenant making some payments but insufficient
Some minor accounting issues but arrears clear
Tenant has made proposals to repay
low_probability: Arrears fallen below threshold by hearing date
Tenant has cleared arrears by hearing
Counterclaim for disrepair reduces arrears below threshold

red_flags: Tenant can prove rent was paid

costs.recoverable_rent: Can claim arrears plus ongoing rent (rent mesne profits)

tenant_defenses: Arrears below threshold at hearing date
Landlord failed to register deposit (makes tenancy periodic)
Tenant has cleared arrears by hearing
notes: Ground 8 is MANDATORY if conditions met - court MUST grant possession if arrears at both notice and hearing. Most commonly used ground. Only 2 weeks notice required. However, strict threshold means many landlords use discretionary Grounds 10/11 as backup.
case_law: Issa v Hackney LBC [1997] - Arrears must exist at both notice and hearing
Bird v Hildage [1948] - Rent account must be accurate
Hayman v Rowlands [1957] - Counterclaims can reduce arrears below threshold
North British Housing Association v Matthews [2004] - Housing Benefit delays considered
court_considerations: Are arrears at threshold at date of notice?
Are arrears still at threshold at date of hearing?
Is there a genuine dispute about the arrears?
